transcript.transcript: It's Friday, December 16th, 1977. This is Karen Wickre talking with Joan Croydon at her home, two Beekman Place in New York City. I'd be interested to know what your previous experience, your training was up to the point of the Federal Theater. Oh, Lord. You don't have to give it all. Well, I started in the theater as a child, eight years old, but I started as a dancer with the Metropolitan Ballet. And then I went to what was the original Washington Square players. It was called the Original Theater Guild. That was the school that started the Theater Guild. And I did work there, and fencing and body training and voice and so forth. And then I did some stock, and I went to the professional children's school, where I was able to be out of town and keep up my schooling. So I went to the Hedgerow Theater, which was very famous in those days outside of Philadelphia, and I spent a season there and. Oh, dear. And then I was with Ethel Barrymore. She was rather interested in me and considered me a protÃ©gÃ©. And so I was the page to Paris in her Romeo and Juliet, which was a disaster. But still it was. I was about 13, 12, I don't know, around there. And I think we better stop a minute, please. Where were we? What was I saying? Ethel Barrymore and, uh. Well, you can take and edit it, I suppose. Have you started it? Yeah. It's on. Oh, um. So this was all in the early 20s? Yeah. And then the. I was also studying, dancing along with the acting. And I suddenly became very interested in Isidor Duncan's work. And her sister Elizabeth came from Salzburg, Austria, and picked me as a girl she wanted to give a scholarship to. So I said, Miss Duncan, I will not teach because I'm going into the theater. And she said, I don't care. So for two years I was in Salzburg, Austria, studying with her. And while I was there, I took part in the Max Reinhardt Festspiele, the art spectacles that they did in Salzburg. Didn't have any speaking parts because my German wasn't that good, but it was an interesting experience. Then the greatest thing that happened to me in my whole life came when I came back from America. I, um, I was in a play with David Belasco, and I had quite a good part. And while I was in that, I heard the miracle was going to be revived. And I don't think you're too young to remember this or have heard about it, but the miracle was Max Reinhart's masterpiece was a play, a pantomime that was done in big theaters, where they did the whole inside like a cathedral. It was just amazing. It had 200 choir and they had orchestra. And the whole thing was a spectacle. And it's a part that I wanted to play, all since I had seen it when I was in school. And he was reviving it. Anyhow, I'm going to go through the whole dramatic. How I got it is tremendous and take too long. But anyhow, I got it. And I had one of the biggest successes in my life, but not in New York on tour, you know, like Detroit and so forth. Yeah. And that was the greatest experience of my life. Then I came back and things went bad. Everything went wrong for me. And then when the Federal Theatre came along, I was sort of desperate because it was a bad time, you know, financially, in every way. My father had died. My mother and I were living on a very small income. We had a house in Pleasantville, New York, which we had taken a home loan on. And so the Federal Theatre came along and I joined it, and we had to lose the house because if you remember or don't remember, I think the salary was $95 a month. Something like that. Yeah. And I think also, you weren't really supposed to own anything like a property. No. So we lost the house, but we managed to live comfortably on that salary. And I was in seventh heaven because I wasn't ever out of work for those years. You know, I think it was 2 or 3 years. Probably the the. I didn't know about you being in Yonkers and all that business was that first before you went into the Roslyn unit? Yes. Yeah. So that must have been early then. 36, I mean, early. No, it was 38. Could it be 38? 39? It could. Well, that could be the only dates I had were in the Roslyn unit and they were all 37, 38. Then it was 36. Yeah. Yeah. It was 2 or 3 years. Was it based in Yonkers? And then you travel around to these other. You mentioned Syracuse? Oh, yes. We went from there to Syracuse for a Clay was taken up there for a week or so and then brought back. That was the only one that was taken up there. I see. But Yonkers, we were stationed there, that we were in the old Warburton Theater. I think it's gone now. And we had worked there constantly. And then, of course, they got the Roslyn Theater after that. Right. And then we were all transported down there. And that was a move we had to make. But. And the company was wonderful. I mean, I always say to people, you know, we weren't the New York City company. We were the New York State Company because I feel we were a better company. It was a lot of political things going on in the New York City company. Yes. Which we had no part of and which we were not. We were an artistic group who were only concerned about doing good plays and doing good performances, you know. And it was a completely different atmosphere. Who gets the credit for that, do you think, for that kind of direction, Would you say? I don't know, I think it was partly the group we had. I think the actors were, um, were giving that atmosphere more than anything else. Mhm. Uh, Danny Malloy, who was an old timer and directed us at the very beginning in Yonkers, was an old time stock director, and he no funny business. He went right to the point of, of the play and there was no other talk. It was just getting the job done. Mhm. And then Charles Hopkins took over in Roslyn. I think he did a very good job. And um all I can say is I'm very grateful for those years and I think we should have another federal theater now because certainly act is not working. It's a similar situation. Exactly, exactly. Now we have a TV commercials to do, you know, to make a living. There are more regional theaters now, and so actors have to go outside of New York to work. Yeah, and none of it is steady or guaranteed. I've been lucky. I was last year. I've been in Pittsburgh and Washington Arena and the O'Neill theater. Really? Yeah. So I have been keeping up by going outside to work. Yeah. You know, and I'm grateful for it. But it's too bad we can't be home in New York. You know. It's. I mean, it's similar. That is also similar to the Federal Theater, you know, having these kind of outposts in Yonkers and going to, I don't know, Syracuse or Buffalo or Albany. We didn't do much of that. I mean, I think Syracuse was the only time I went. So you mostly stayed. And did you say White Plains also? You just. White Plains we yes, we did work in White Plains for a little while. I was just at the very beginning, you know. Um, how did those kind of audiences who perhaps had not, were not so familiar with theater? Maybe they were, I don't know, how did they like what you did? Well, as I remember, they were the most enthusiastic. Yeah. We didn't do two, two We did things that they could understand, you know, and relate to. I would think it would have been. I mean, there was Coriolanus was done in Rosslyn. That's a very arty Shakespeare production, you know, and I guess people came from New York to see that. And the people that lived in that part of of the world were interested. I don't know how why planes would have been, I don't know, Yonkers would have been interested in it. Mhm. I wonder who somebody must have been. Um, in charge of picking the kinds of plays that would be seen in places where, you know, theater was not so prevalent for him. Yeah. I guess the general, uh, um, what was his name? Louis. Simon. Oh, I know, yeah. Louis Simon was very good, but there was another. Person. Who was in Syracuse who was in charge of the whole state thing. Uh, I can't remember his name. His name? Terrible. Huh? I can't either. Oh, A peak begins with P. Petrie. Petrie. No, no. Well. Palmerton. Guy. Palmerton. Oh, okay. Yeah, right. Yeah, I know that name. In Syracuse, I think in charge of a great deal of Enron. Mhm. Yeah. Did you, uh, go to Maxine Elliott's theatre when there was that short run, I think. Yeah, I think I did Coriolanus there. Yeah, yeah, yeah. Frank Dailey told me about that. Was that note markedly different for you? I mean, to. Yeah. Well, you played in New York theaters before, but, um, I don't know were. The audience is different. How did they respond to this? I don't know how they perceived this group. Oh, I think it was given great credit and given, you know, good notices because it was, uh, it was it was good production. Mhm. But I remember being very distinctly, uh, Trying to be explicit. When I said I was the Federal Theatre, I always said, but not New York City. I was so afraid they'd think I was part of that. You mean you. Knew all along of all the troubles they were having and the labor business? Yes. And it was it was too bad because the federal theater should have been free of all that, you know. It should have been what we had in the state. We should have a company who were anxious to work in the craft they knew, and in a sincere and constructive way, and not have any outside business going on. Did you live in Roslyn during that time? Yes, my mother and I did, yeah. It sounds almost like it was not really communal, but a very close knit. It was. Yeah. We were like a family. Mhm. Very much so. In fact, a lot of us have kept up our friendship, you know, like Frank and Jay Bailey. And he's up in Larchmont. Yes. Yeah. Good friends of ours. How about, um, Erford Gage? I've heard a lot about him. Oh, my gosh. How great he was. Oh, such a talent. Such a shame to be cut off just then. Yeah, because when he did his company in Boston, he was directing and acting. He did the Royal family. And he was wonderful as the John Barrymore part, you know. And I was Julia, Julie and oh, the critics, every critic, there were eight critics in Boston. All gave us raves. It was wonderful. And Night Must Fall was a very big success too. Mhm. He had a great success. That was the last thing he did. Really. Yeah. I'm trying to think of other um, cast names, although I know. Helen Walker was with us. She went to Hollywood and did some very good things for a while, and I think she became an alcoholic or something. Something happened. Awful happened to her. What happened to Dan Malloy? Oh, yes. Oh. He died. Uh, um, uh, another actor who became very famous, uh, and he died a few years ago. Um. Oh, dear. Oh, well, he wasn't, um. No, he was with the Boston Company. He wasn't that. Oh, dear. That's right. I'm sorry. I'm getting used to. He was in Boston. Oh. Did you go to Boston? Um. I mean, did you move to Boston and work there? No. You just. I was there for two plays, Royal family. And I must have been, what, 39, 40? 40. 39, I. Think. Did you, um, kind of follow the downfall of the Federal Theater and, you know, all the the investigations and the business about it about to end? No, I left, you know, I got I got a job in you can't take it with you. This I remember, uh, Sam Harris production that went on the road. And I remember leaving Rosslyn to go in this production, which left. That's when I left the Federal Theatre. I see. I think that was 39. And it would have been. Yeah. Before the end then. Mhm. So I was out of it before they closed. Yeah. Did it surprise you to hear about it ending. I don't remember what I was surprised or not. But I certainly think that now is the time for something like that to happen. They could take the Beaumont Theater. Yes. Exactly. Yeah. A lot of people have been have been echoing that for sure. I was in a in a company that was, uh, since then, it was the best company. I've talked to William Ball's company, American Conservatory Theater. Mhm. Which we started in, in Pittsburgh. And I was in San Francisco. That's right. I was there with him for a year and a half. Wow. It was marvelous. I keep hoping he would come back to New York, but he. He doesn't like me. What? And what did you do at Arena Cats? Play. Oh, this is This last year. If she were there. You're near there, aren't you? Yeah. Did you hear about it? Oh, yeah. It was a big hit. I know I didn't go to that production I had. I had a subscription which lapsed, and I wasn't sure if I was going to stay in the area. I didn't go to that one. Oh, it was wonderful. It was sold out. We were sold out the whole time we were there. Yeah. Wonderful. And then Helen Burns, who played the lead, was so great. And she did it again in the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. And I hear in March is going to come here Off Broadway. I'm not sure, but I hear it should it should come more on Broadway than off Broadway because I think it's worth it. Yeah. Yeah. No, I heard very good things about it. So you've kept up, um, kind of in rep, not repertory work, but, um, in regional theater and that kind of thing. All. All during this time or you were on Broadway, I know. Oh, yes. After that. Oh, yes, I was in Broadway. I mean, I did Potting Shed with Dame Sybil Thorndike and got the Clarence Derwent Award for Best Supporting Performance. And I did, uh, compulsion with Roddy McDowell. Oh, yeah. Um, well. How about, uh, the heel? The purification, the bad seed. The bad seed. Of course, the bad seed was before potting shed and before compulsion. And then I did the Hollywood film of that scene. Um. Six characters. Oh, of course, that was the greatest. That was so exciting. Yeah, that was William. That's how I got into his company. I see. He directed that. That's right. Yeah. This is maybe an old list, I don't know, just from the New York Times theater directory. Yeah. Yeah. That's how we. Found the six characters. That was a year and a half of Bill ball. You see, after that, uh, a year elapsed. I think six characters was 63, 64 was nothing really. And then 65, we did the American Conservatory Theater in Pittsburgh. And then there was a year and a half more of that was 67, and then went to England with my husband for two years because he had to be there for his mother's estate. And it's hard suddenly to think of all the together. Yeah. It's difficult. Yeah I know. Yeah. Do you remember, um, well, anything that stand out about any of the productions now? The federal. Um hum. Oh, I think Captain Jinks was one of the most beautiful. But Ben was only 18 or something then, and his his talent was so obvious. I mean, those costumes were. Oh, yeah. And made beautiful so much more elaborate than you can believe they would have had money for. Yeah. Yeah. For sure. Yeah. How about, um. No more peace. Do you remember that one? Yes I know. And I didn't care for it very much. Frankly. I wondered how it seemed like it would have been slightly more controversial play than the kinds of things that you were doing. It was it was much more social, really. Yeah. It was. And I don't know, I wasn't so keenly interested in political things at that time, and I don't think I was terribly involved in it. Did you? I thought that I read somewhere that Hallie Flanagan came out and saw that, and was impressed with it and wanted it to go somewhere else. I believe I remember, yes, vaguely, I remember that, yeah. But, you know, there are rumors always in a company like that. Yeah. This is going to happen. That's going to happen. You sort of sort of take it for granted. Yeah. That's true. You see. I guess the Roslyn unit went on till the end of the Federal Theater. I believe it. Did. But I wasn't. No, I know you left, but I couldn't remember. It was just after the Federal Theater closed that Erford Gage went to Boston and did that company. That's right. That's when I went in. Then I came back from You Can't Take it with you and went with him. When you were in Roslyn, did you have a a year long or close to a year long season? It wasn't just a resort. Oh, no. It was a year round. Oh, we were there in winter, too. Oh, yes. Yeah. It was a theater that worked the whole year through, not just the summer. I'm just curious about why he wouldn't establish it there, but it was already his theater. Hopkins was a darling little theater already there, you know, perfect. The right size, the right atmosphere, the place to rehearse. Everything was right. It was a jewel of a place. How was he to work under Charles Hopkins? He's gone, isn't he? I think so. I didn't care for him. I was just a personal thing. But did you have to have much dealing with him? Not too much. No, not too much. Your directors you could get along with? Yes. I can't remember who the different directors were. Molloy. Molloy. And who directed, uh. Who directed that? I don't know. This one doesn't say. It says staged by Charles Hopkins. Oh, well, he did it. Yes he. Did. Some of the others. I thought Molloy had done most of them, and I'd heard the things about him. He knew his business. He brought up in it. That's all he ever did in his life was theatre. And he knew. Did he stay with you or did he go on to films or did he? Oh, he was an older man here. Oh, I didn't know that. Oh, yes. He was in his 60s. Yes. Hopkins. Did you you did direct. Under the personal direction of. So is the. I haven't heard from JB, although I have written to. Is he, uh, still extant? Oh, he's still here. I, uh, last year I made a date for he and Frank Daly to come here for dinner. And then the blackout. Oh, yes. And all my food went blah, and I said, I can't. I can't stand it. I can't have you for dinner during all this business. So we postponed it. And I haven't had him yet, but I was thinking of J. I must get Ahold of him. He's quite honored. Yes. I understand, but it surprised me to see his picture because he looks. Yeah, but he must be 89. Yeah. So, uh, we're anxious to get him here before anything happens to him. That he will, because he's always been very active. Active? Yeah. Well, do you have any, uh, concluding remarks about the Federal theater? I know you said you'd like to see another one. Oh, I'd love to see another one. Run the same way and the same national scope and that kind of thing. Oh, I don't know. I suppose they can learn from experience. I should think those looking up the wreckage, you would maybe see the flaws in it, you know, and correct them. I think anything like that has to be run with very good people at the head. Otherwise it doesn't go. Is your sense of Hallie Flanagan that she was good or. I guess so. I mean, I just accepted the job as I had it as an actress and didn't criticize or try to probe what was wrong if there was anything wrong. I can't remember anything wrong. I can't remember except that the money. But nobody was getting any more than that. Yeah. You know, you have to go on relief, incidentally. Home releases. I don't remember. That. That's funny. My mother had to go on relief. Yeah. Uh, we had a period. I can remember it. It was during the World's Fair. It was 39, 40 where we were very hard up. Mother went on relief and had tickets and things, you know. Yeah, food tickets. The ration things. Yeah, I remember that. And I remember walking from Broadway to Bank Street, where we lived to save money, to buy a loaf of bread. I remember that tough times. And that late, too. You know, many people were saying, including people that wanted to get rid of the WPA, were saying, well, by now, you know, the depression is really over. Yeah. But, uh, but. No, I had quite a few years of pretty tough sledding. Yeah. Well, a number of people, I mean, they had a quota that a certain number didn't have to be on relief. So maybe if you don't remember, you might have gotten in on that. Mhm. How could you not be on relief. They had because they knew that there were some people that they just couldn't find otherwise. I mean mostly I think it was maybe um Writers or directors or, you know, some technical people, but I know some actors would also come in. I think, um, for instance, um, let's see, there was a in a Los Angeles federal theater. They had a big, um, production of a Shakespeare play and brought in Estelle Winwood, and she wasn't on release. But they knew that in order to draw people, you know, they they'd pay her sort of like a consultant, I think. And that way they would get, you know, and it also would lend some luster to the Federal Theater to say, well, we have, you know, well. I think the nice thing about our company was there were no names, Charles Hopkins name, no names as far as actors or anybody concerned. And yet we I think we were pretty successful. People came to see the play and the performance, but that was outside of New York. You see, I don't know what happened in New York, but I had a feeling that a lot of people were in the New York project who had no business to be in it. With it being so big. People just got in, you know, with not the background to. That's another thing. When a thing like that happens, there's an awful lot of freeloaders and you've got to you've got to have somebody to know actors and know those who are worthwhile. Being in a company like that don't support actors who are just taking advantage of to learn the craft or something. Yeah. Yeah. Well, that's something that should definitely be. I think that was a problem before. Not everywhere. No, but I don't think in our company we had anybody that wasn't really had been in the theater before the Federal Theater. That's the important thing, I think in New York City there were a lot who weren't. Yeah. Yeah. Did you know about the other units throughout the country about anything that there were other units? Oh, I guess I. Did, but I didn't know much about what they were doing. That happened quite a bit around New York. I mean, that, uh, these kind of outposts. I mean, Los Angeles had a big unit in Chicago and Seattle, surprisingly enough. And, you know, a few other places had rather large units. But whenever we, you know, talk to those people, of course, they knew about what was going on and they knew about New York. But many people in New York. Well, you know. What is the what is the thing? What what did you in your probing of this thing? What did you find out? Did you feel that that that was a success throughout the country, or was it just a. Yes or no? Well, um, in the beginning, they were sort of too ambitious and opened a lot of units in places that really couldn't sustain them. Mhm. But after it kind of settled down after the first couple of years, there were good productions in Chicago and Seattle and Los Angeles and you know less well. I mean a lot of I can't really it's not fair to say just because there were old stock shows that they weren't successful, you know, but they did do a lot of that in these smaller places, Denver or, you know, Tulsa or Dallas or something, but, um, I, I think that it really was all things considered. I mean, to think of even doing something that would involve that much bureaucracy today would be hard to imagine, you know? Then there was really one person at the head, and it was confusing all the administrative stuff. I know because I looked at those records. But, um, considering, you know, at the peak, I guess there were about 12,000 people working under it. And it's a lot of people and they they estimated at one point that they'd played to 25 million Americans. That's great. And, you know. Yeah, there's nothing like that. I mean, unless you want to start talking about television or film. Yeah. That's great. But for, you know, live theater, for getting it to people who had never seen it. I think it might have been easier now to start a federal theater because of the regional theater success. Yeah. That's true. You know, the audiences are wanting to go because they've been trained by the regional theaters of Pittsburgh. I did Uncle Vanya. Public theaters and public theaters. Yeah. Very good. Excellent. I think that's another thing. I think that came out of Federal Theater. It started to I mean, maybe some of these regional theaters exist because interest got kindled. Maybe then or in the 40s or 50s. Yeah, yeah, sometimes. There's a theater in Buffalo and. Oh, yeah. Pittsburgh and Washington and now Atlanta. Yeah. Kentucky. All over the place. Mhm. Do you hold out any hope for the, uh, uh, National Endowment for the Arts or Humanities? Do you have any sense that they can be helpful in this regard? I don't know, I hope so. I think the good company should be supported. Yeah. I think that, uh, I've always been for Bill ball, but he spends money like water and he's always out of money. But I think he has The jeans. And I think, of course, the ranger is doing wonderful work. Yeah, I think so. They're the oldest. Aren't they. Wonderful? Yeah, I guess they must be. Yeah. I think it's one of the oldest theatre in the round, aren't you? I was with Margo Jones, which was the beginning of the theatre here. When was that? 53. 53. Before the Bad Seed. And she was wonderful. She was really wonderful. She did. She did only new scripts, which was marvelous. And one classic during the nine month season. Mhm. So she had a staff of readers who picked out the plays. They were so many, you know, she was famous for this. And she'd pick, they'd pick out and she'd read it and then they'd select eight plays for the season. And we spent three weeks rehearsing and three weeks playing. And while we were playing, the plays to rehearse three weeks in a day, you know. And it was constant working rehearsal, daytime performance at night for nine months. It was mobbed. It was wonderful. She did good work. Some of the federal theatre units did work along that way in Yonkers. I don't know how I did it, I really don't, because I played all the leads and I would rehearse in the morning at ten, say, and rehearse till four, and then come back and try to learn my lines and then give a performance that night and go home after the performance and learn the lines for the next week. It was a weekly thing. Yeah. So I was up most of the night all that time learning the next week's production. I don't know how I did it, I really don't. Now I look back on it. It was just slavery. And in the theater, the Four Seasons had that repertory group too, where you, you know, rotate those. Yes. You see a lot of work and work, but then when you're young, you don't mind that, you know, That is part of your experience. Oh, sure. And it's great. I mean, who today is doing a program like that where young people can get that experience. Or with the new place? Well, these weren't new, but I mean, as you were saying, Margaret Jones. Oh. And I mean, in New York City, there was this big play readers unit that was supposed to be doing this, you know. But we didn't do any new. Things. Yeah. Well, I think they should have. You should have. But I also think that, um, it was sort of the goal of maybe Hopkins and maybe Simon. I don't know. And I know Hallie Flanagan supported this idea of having one repertory theater, at least, that did that kind of thing exclusively. Well, Margot had Inherit the Wind from her company and suffered smoke. Two of the plays that came from her company. Yeah. And they've lived on. Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah. Yeah. She was wonderful. Wonderful.

lines.line: > The speaker began her theater career as a child, initially training as a dancer with the Metropolitan Ballet. She later joined the Washington Square players, which evolved into the Theater Guild, where she received comprehensive training in various aspects of theater. Her early career also included working with notable figures such as Ethel Barrymore and studying under Isadora Duncan's sister in Salzburg, Austria. These experiences shaped her early career and introduced her to significant theatrical opportunities.

metadata.title: Early Beginnings and Training
metadata.synopsis: The speaker began her theater career as a child, initially training as a dancer with the Metropolitan Ballet. She later joined the Washington Square players, which evolved into the Theater Guild, where she received comprehensive training in various aspects of theater. Her early career also included working with notable figures such as Ethel Barrymore and studying under Isadora Duncan's sister in Salzburg, Austria. These experiences shaped her early career and introduced her to significant theatrical opportunities.

lines.line: > The speaker recounts her time with the Federal Theatre as a pivotal period in her life, marked by both significant professional engagement and personal financial struggles. Despite the hardships, such as losing her family home, she found stability in the constant work provided by the Federal Theatre. This period was crucial for her, providing both a steady income during tough economic times and a platform to continue her acting career.

metadata.title: Experiences with the Federal Theatre
metadata.synopsis: The speaker recounts her time with the Federal Theatre as a pivotal period in her life, marked by both significant professional engagement and personal financial struggles. Despite the hardships, such as losing her family home, she found stability in the constant work provided by the Federal Theatre. This period was crucial for her, providing both a steady income during tough economic times and a platform to continue her acting career.

lines.line: > After her time with the Federal Theatre, the speaker continued her acting career, working under various directors and participating in significant productions across the country. She reflects on the different theatrical experiences she had, including working with the American Conservatory Theater and participating in productions that received critical acclaim. Her career post-Federal Theatre was marked by a series of successful roles that kept her engaged in the theater scene outside New York.

metadata.title: Post-Federal Theatre Career
metadata.synopsis: After her time with the Federal Theatre, the speaker continued her acting career, working under various directors and participating in significant productions across the country. She reflects on the different theatrical experiences she had, including working with the American Conservatory Theater and participating in productions that received critical acclaim. Her career post-Federal Theatre was marked by a series of successful roles that kept her engaged in the theater scene outside New York.

lines.line: > The speaker reflects on the Federal Theatre's impact, noting its national scope and the opportunities it provided for actors during the Great Depression. She expresses a desire to see a similar initiative today, recognizing the potential benefits of a national theater program. The speaker also discusses the administrative challenges and the eventual closure of the Federal Theatre, suggesting that lessons from its operation could inform future endeavors in national theater projects.

metadata.title: Reflections on the Federal Theatre
metadata.synopsis: The speaker reflects on the Federal Theatre's impact, noting its national scope and the opportunities it provided for actors during the Great Depression. She expresses a desire to see a similar initiative today, recognizing the potential benefits of a national theater program. The speaker also discusses the administrative challenges and the eventual closure of the Federal Theatre, suggesting that lessons from its operation could inform future endeavors in national theater projects.

children.text: > The speaker began her theater career as a child, initially training as a dancer with the Metropolitan Ballet. She later joined the Washington Square players, which evolved into the Theater Guild, where she received comprehensive training in various aspects of theater. Her early career also included working with notable figures such as Ethel Barrymore and studying under Isadora Duncan's sister in Salzburg, Austria. These experiences shaped her early career and introduced her to significant theatrical opportunities.

> The speaker recounts her time with the Federal Theatre as a pivotal period in her life, marked by both significant professional engagement and personal financial struggles. Despite the hardships, such as losing her family home, she found stability in the constant work provided by the Federal Theatre. This period was crucial for her, providing both a steady income during tough economic times and a platform to continue her acting career.

> After her time with the Federal Theatre, the speaker continued her acting career, working under various directors and participating in significant productions across the country. She reflects on the different theatrical experiences she had, including working with the American Conservatory Theater and participating in productions that received critical acclaim. Her career post-Federal Theatre was marked by a series of successful roles that kept her engaged in the theater scene outside New York.

> The speaker reflects on the Federal Theatre's impact, noting its national scope and the opportunities it provided for actors during the Great Depression. She expresses a desire to see a similar initiative today, recognizing the potential benefits of a national theater program. The speaker also discusses the administrative challenges and the eventual closure of the Federal Theatre, suggesting that lessons from its operation could inform future endeavors in national theater projects.

story.title: Joan Croydon, December 16, 1977
